results.title: Green and gold greats
results.brief_description: This program brings together a fifty year span of Australian sporting splendour including performances of Don Bradman, Dawn Fraser, Heather McKay, Walter Lindrum, Majorie Jackson, Betty Cuthbert, Herb Helliot, Peter Thomson, Les Darcy, Vic Patrick, Merwyn Wood, Lew Hoad, Ken Rosewall and Phar Lap.

results.title: Green
results.brief_description: Surfing set to music - documentary footage of professional male surfers from four locations across the world and featuring some 50 surfers. Heaps of slow-motion short-board action and a few wipeouts just to keep things interesting. Shot in Mexico, Australia, California, and Hawaii by producer/director Matt Wybenga. Some of the surfers featured include: Joel Parkinson, Mick Fanning, Andy Irons, Kelly Slater and Taj Burrow. Music includes artists DJ Shadow, Ziggy Marley, Single Handed and Coal Chamber.

results.title: Greek tragic theatre (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Brenton Holmes and Department of Further Education, South Australia
results.brief_description: Examines the elements of Greek Tragedy - looking in particular at Euripides and Sophocles, their themes, theatrical styles and cultural significance.

results.title: Greek curriculum
results.creator_credit: Dimitri Man and Victoria. Dept. of Education and Early Childhood Development
results.brief_description: The Greek Curriculum program is designed for children in Australian schools catering for the mother tongue and second language learners. The same program is repeated twice. The first has English subtitles and Greek dialogue whilst the second is in Greek only.

results.title: Greek children
results.brief_description: Daily activities of a boy and girl in Galaxidi, a fishing village in southern Greece; chores of the girl and other womenfolk, the boy’s friendship with the village Shepard who teaches him to play the flute; the boy and his father travel to Athens in an old fishing boat; views of the Acropolis.

results.title: Greece: So rich, so poor
results.brief_description: Reviews the problems impending the development of Greece in ancient and modern times. Discusses the economy, agriculture, and education of Greece and the challenge for Greece’s future.

results.title: Greece: playground of the gods
results.creator_credit: Chip Duncan, Peter May, Crouse Entertainment and International Video Network
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Video visits”.
Greece is a land rich in natural beauty, history and tradition; its sun-drenched islands surrounded by sparkling water. Travelling through the countryside exposes the tourist to a wealth of history and and myth; whether it be at the Acropolis, the home of the Gods in Athens or in Crete where the ruins of Knossos and the legendary palace of King Midas can be found. Visit the Plaka where the locals sip Greek coffee and discuss politics and life, see the magnificent windmills of Mykonos and admire some of the finest ancient classical architecture ever constructed.

results.title: Greece: North and South; Athens
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Travel, Travel”.
This travel video begins in the Halkidiki region of northern Greece, site of centuries-old monasteries. From Halkidiki we move to the city of Thessaloniki which is full of the influence of not only Greek and Roman civilisation but also Venetian and Arab. The travels continue south to the coastal regions of the Pelyponnese. In the second part we explore Athens: including the taverns of Plaka, the flea markets in Monasteraki, the original Olympic Stadium and , of-course, the Parthenon and the Acropolis.

results.title: Greece the immortal land
results.creator_credit: Realist Films, Gladys Wright and Basil Wright
results.brief_description: An evocative documentary showing Greece as the background to western civilisation. The artistic treasures of antiquity are seen side by side with the life of the sturdy people today. Contains many spectacular shots of the Parthenon, the ruins of Mistra and Mycenae and the sunbaked landscape along with candid camera sequences of the Greeks of today. Independently financed, this film aroused lively critical comment in Great Britain.
